Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the increase in Medicare premiums, stating that they will go up to $247.00 in 2014, when in reality the official monthly premium for 2012 is $99.90.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide any evidence or sources to support the statement that the premium increases are due to provisions in the Obamacare legislation.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the premium increases were purposely delayed to avoid confusion during the 2012 re-election campaigns, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the official monthly premium for Medicare Part B premiums in 2012 is $99.90, not $104.20 as stated in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by using incorrect numbers and inaccurate information about Medicare premiums.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanations for the increase in Medicare premiums.
